snippet: The identity of the Tunisian, Anis Amri, who had been labeled a security threat and was supposed to have been deported months ago, alarmed intelligence officials....
abstract: Anis Amri, Tunisian suspect in Berlin truck attack, was known to have ties to extremists and was on watch lists in United States and Europe; Amri had been detained in Germany pending deportation proceedings, but was freed; failures on part of German authorities have further embattled Chancellor Angela Merkel in her decision to admit nearly million asylum seekers.

byline.original: By MELISSA EDDY, JACK EWING, JOANNA BERENDT and ERIC SCHMITT
byline.contributor: Melissa Eddy reported from Berlin, Jack Ewing from Frankfurt, Joanna Berendt from Warsaw and Eric Schmitt from Washington. Alison Smale and Franziska Reymann contributed reporting from Berlin, and Sewell Chan from London.

lead_paragraph: The identity of the Tunisian, Anis Amri, who had been labeled a security threat and was supposed to have been deported months ago, alarmed intelligence officials.

headline.main: Berlin Attack Sets Off Hunt for a Tunisian in Germany
headline.print_headline: Suspect Hunted in Berlin Attack Was Well Known
